message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken()
<<<code>>>: The error is occurring in the line where the StringTokenizer.nextToken() method is called.
<<<explanation>>>: The error message "java.util.NoSuchElementException" indicates that there are no more tokens available to be retrieved from the StringTokenizer. This means that the StringTokenizer has reached the end of the input string and there are no more tokens to be extracted.

In your code, the error is occurring in the line where you are calling st.nextToken() inside the for loop. This means that the StringTokenizer has already extracted all the tokens from the savedString and there are no more tokens left to be retrieved.

To fix this issue, you need to check if there are more tokens available before calling st.nextToken(). You can do this by using the hasMoreTokens() method of the StringTokenizer class. Here's an updated version of your code:

```
StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(savedString, ",");
for (int i = 0; i < keys.length && st.hasMoreTokens(); i++) {
    keys[i] = Boolean.valueOf(st.nextToken());
}
```

By adding the condition `st.hasMoreTokens()` in the for loop, you ensure that the loop will only execute if there are more tokens available to be retrieved. This will prevent the "java.util.NoSuchElementException" error from occurring.
